    Head N (cont) -

    Resumption of Debate on Question [15th March, 1978],

    Question again proposed.

     The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Tan Eng Liang): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the hon. Member for Kim Seng has requested information on the physical development of Kent Ridge Hospital. Kent Ridge Hospital has been planned for construction in two phases as a general hospital with facilities for clinical teaching. A total of 752 beds will be provided when the

Column: 939

project is completed. The planning and design work for the hospital was completed in April 1977. Architectural, mechanical, electrical, structural, quantity surveying and site clearance work are in progress. Barring any unforeseen delays, it is expected that major earthworks will commence in the second quarter and piling in the third quarter of this year. The building for Phase I is expected to commence in January 1979 and to be completed in January 1983. The facilities to be completed under Phase I will include 485 beds for medicine, surgery and orthopaedics for principal diagnostic treatment, academic departments, area for administration, the central plant and areas for supportive services such as pharmacy, kitchen, central sterile supplies department, linen, etc.

    The building for Phase II is scheduled to commence in July 1982 and expected to be completed in July 1985. The facilities for Phase II will include 267 beds for paediatrics, ENT, obstetrics and gynaecology, the departments for social medicine and public health, the remainder of the academic offices, laboratories and the dental faculty.

    The total cost of the project is estimated to be $144,203,150. The estimated cost for Phase I is $115,313,925. The estimated cost for Phase II is $28,889,225.

     Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Seng): Sir, from the data provided by the Senior Minister of State for National Development, it would appear that the Hospital will not be ready for service until 1983. And for Phase II, it will probably be 1985. Does it mean, therefore, that the present medical school will be shifted to the new hospital grounds in phases only after 1983?

    Secondly, would the facilities in the now hospital be as adequate and up to-date as the facilities at present found at the Singapore General Hospital?

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, I presume that the standard of the facilities would be at least equivalent, if not better than the facilities at the Singapore General Hospital. The reason is that there are two Planning committees for

Column: 940

the Kent Ridge project. One Planning committee is under the Chairmanship of the Director of Medical Services with a number of medical experts. Another Executive Planning committee is under Professor Tock with a number of professors from the various departments. As far as the facilities are concerned, I assume that they will be up to the standard.

    With regard to the medical school, I understand that it is not the intention to have teaching facilities that will take over the entire existing teaching facilities at the Singapore General Hospital. I understand that most hospitals will have some form of teaching facilities. Perhaps the entire University medical department may be shifted to the new hospital.

     Dr Ong Leong Boon: Sir, in the Senior Minister of State's reply, I notice that two operative words were used. One is that he "presumes" facilities will be adequate. I do not think it is satisfactory for him to say "I presume" because if he presumes, then I may assume.

    Secondly, the Senior Minister of State also said that because of the presence of professors on the Planning committees, therefore he assumes that the facilities will be adequate. We know that a hospital, besides service vocations, should also have a commitment for research work. We know that much of the decision depends on the planning and perhaps the cooperation of the Ministry of Finance. Can we have more definite answers rather than using words like "presume" and "assume"?

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, the Ministry of National Development is responsible for the planning and implementation of the project. As for the internal facilities like medical equipment and staff, I think that could best be answered by the Minister for Health because we are in no position to answer, I therefore presume or I can even assume that since there are medical experts on the relevant committees, they will get the best of facilities that are available in 1985 for the new hospital.

     Dr Ong Leong Boon: Sir, in spite of the "assumes" and "presumes", I take it that it is outside the Senior Minister of State's jurisdiction to really give a satisfactory reply in that respect. I think he has given a good answer, and I beg leave to withdraw the amendment.

     Mr P. Govindaswamy (Anson): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head N be reduced by $10 in respect of item 1210 of Subhead Code NC-01 of the Main Estimates.

    I am pleased to note that after having raised an issue last year about an accident prone area at the deadly bend around the Kampong Bahru/Kampong Lama Roads, an immediate improvement has been carried out by the Department concerned by erecting a metal barrier along the bend. This barrier has definitely prevented further accidents in that area which is evident as the barrier is damaged every now and then and is replaced. Anyway, this is the best that the Department could do at the moment.

    Sir, on the question of road improvements in my constituency, that stretch of Keppel Road near Customs House to Anson Road is frequently congested with traffic. This is because of the traffic signals at the closely spaced road junctions in the area. This stretch of the road is part of a key mad for traffic from the city to the western sector of the island and also vice versa. Even the traffic lights do not seem to be synchronised.

    It is true that road widening is taking place at the moment to improve the flow of traffic. In the near future, a road would be constructed from Tanjong Rhu passing through the reclaimed land and is expected to be joined to this already congested road. And because of the present closely spaced traffic lights, the traffic snarl may still exist. My purpose in raising this issue is that in the long term planning, the roads in this area like Cantonment Road, Keppel Road, Tanjong Pagar Road, Anson Road and all the other subsidiary roads should be reviewed carefully. Further improvements should be

Column: 942

carried out so that there will be less traffic lights and interruption to the free flow of traffic could be avoided.

    Further down Anson Road near the junction of Maxwell Road, the area there is also very complicated both for motorists and pedestrians. The many roads meeting at that point result in frequent traffic jams during peak periods. Because of the new law on jaywalking, many pedestrians find it very confusing when commuting in this area.

    Sir, the traffic-congestion problem is not peculiar only in my constituency. There are also other areas in the city where such problem exists. In order to resolve the traffic congestion problem, the Ministry in its long-term planning should take my views into consideration.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, the Member for Anson has commented on two salient points; (1) traffic jams occur frequently along the stretch of road from Keppel Road to Anson Road, and (2) the traffic lights do not synchronise at this stretch. The traffic jams that occur along this stretch of road are due to the narrow width of the road and also to the three closely spaced road junctions that the Member has mentioned, namely, the Cantonment, Tanjong Pagar and Anson Roads. This section of Keppel Road is presently being widened and road works are expected to be completed in about four months' time.

    With regard to the traffic lights, Keppel Road at the moment carries traffic in both directions and, therefore, it will not be possible to provide progressive green phases at the signalised junctions for both directions of traffic. This progressive green phase can only be provided in one direction. However, new signal controllers will be installed in conjunction with the proposed computerised traffic signal control system which is expected to be commissioned around the end of 1979 or 1980.

    The other area of congestion along Anson Road is due to the narrow section of Anson Road between Parsi Road and Keppel Road which also carries two directional traffic.

Shenton Way at the moment is being extended to connect with Keppel Road. When completed, Shenton Way and Anson Road will be turned into a one-way pair, thus resolving the present congestion along this stretch of Anson Road.

    The traffic signals along Keppel Road/Anson Road and Shenton Way will incorporate the red man/green man signals. Hopefully they will help to facilitate pedestrian movement. We will take up his suggestion and liaise with the Traffic Police or the Ministry of Home Affairs to look into other areas which cause difficulties to pedestrians crossing road junctions.

     Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)( In Mandarin): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head N be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead Code NC-01 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, the PWD has contributed a lot to the task of road building and public communication network, and the city has become cleaner and modernised, compatible with other metropolis. The PWD has constructed walkways along the pavements of shops in the city and laid them with good quality tiles. These places have been renovated so as to give a pleasing atmosphere to pedestrians and visitors to these thoroughfares. Undoubtedly, this beautification programme has been well received by the people, and praised by tourists. I feel that the programme should be extended to other areas. For this reason, I would request the Minister to consider constructing the same public walkways along Bah Tan Road in Sembawang. There are two primary schools and one secondary school in this area, with several thousand pupils of tender age. If there are walkways along this road, they will provide safe passage for the

Column: 944

children and facilitate their commuting from one side of the road to the other.

    Secondly, I would like to ask the Minister when will the widening of the road stretching from Thomson Road to Sembawang Road be completed. And how will the resettlement of the residents and shopkeepers affected by the widening of roads in Sembawang be dealt with? I would like to ask the Minister to consider their case sympathetically, particularly in giving them rental concessions to minimise their hardship.

     The Chairman: Mr Teong, you are talking about resettlement. That topic is not in the discussion on this amendment.

     Mr Teong Eng Siong( In Mandarin): Sir, although it has no direct bearing, it is indirectly connected with the topic under discussion, as the Departments concerned are closely inter-related. I would like the Department concerned to alleviate the hardship of those affected by the widening of roads.

    Thirdly, I would like to ask the Minister about the new road in Naval Base, stretching from Admiralty Road to Marsiling Road. According to my understanding, work on this new road has been going on for more than two years. There seems to be a delay in the construction of the road. Therefore, the residents in Marsiling and Sembawang are anxious that this mad is completed as soon as possible as it would ease their transport problems.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, I would like to assure the Member for Sembawang that there is a comprehensive programme for walkways in the urban and suburban areas. As to his request for standards of walkways similar to those at Shenton Way, I cannot see the possibility of his request being granted. Perhaps he is requesting for footpaths rather than walkways. If that is so, it can be considered and I would raise this matter with the Urban and Rural Services Committee.

    With regard to his wanting to know more about the widening of Upper Thomson Road and Sembawang Road, I can inform him that this is being carried out in three stages. The

Column: 945

section of Upper Thomson Road from Sembawang Hill Circus to Mandai Road is under construction and is expected to be completed at the end of the year. The next section of Sembawang Road, from Mandai Road to Jalan Sembawang Kechil, is already completed. For the final section, subject to resettlement and clearance of affected stretches on time, tenders for the widening of Sembawang Road, from Jalan Sembawang Kechil to Admiralty Road, is scheduled to be called in May this year and we hope to complete it by early 1980. I can assure the Member that fair compensation and resettlement benefits will be given to those affected by resettlement, provided they are genuine resettlement cases.

    On his third query about the situation of the roadworks from Admiralty Road to Marsiling Road, there are a few roads connecting these two main roads. Three of them, namely, Riverside Road, Marsiling Lane and Marsiling Drive, are already completed. The remaining link is the proposed Woodlands Centre Road. This is a major road which would cross four existing trunk water mains. The construction of this stretch of road has to be planned in conjunction with the protection of these water mains. Therefore, it cannot be completed earlier than 1980.

     Mr Teong Eng Siong( In Mandarin): Sir, the Senior Minister of State's reply is quite satisfactory, and I beg leave to withdraw my amendment.

    Amendment by leave, withdrawn.

    That the sum to be allocated for Head N be reduced by $10 in respect of item 1210 of Subhead Code NC-03 of the Main Estimates.

    That the sum to be allocated for Head N be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead Code N C-04 of the Main Estimates.

    Last year Singapore saw a disturbing phenomenon. After three days of torrential rain our clean and green city was turned into a great puddle. We have all heard the explanation given to this House by the Hon. Senior Minister of State that the rapid road deterioration was caused by diesel spillage. Now, if this is the sole reason, then we can expect the problem to be a perennial one. Last year for the first time as far as I can remember there was such large scale deterioration and therefore it is highly improbable that diesel spillage alone was the cause. From observations made at the time, it was noted that the deterioration did not necessarily occur in places where there had been heavy diesel spillage or that the roads were necessarily old. I wonder if the PWD had carried out a survey to ascertain whether most, if not all, of the deteriorated roads were the work of one or perhaps two contractors and whether there was proper control of the quality of materials and workmanship. Would the Hon. Minister please tell the House what steps have been taken to ensure that there will not be a repetition of the occurrence? It is bad enough to see a few patches of road deteriorating through wear and tear, but to see the city roads turned into a succession of puddles almost overnight is certainly intolerable.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, the Member for Telok Blangah could be referring to the Oral Answer given to the Question tabled by the Member for Thomson on 31st January, 1978. In the Oral Answer, I have indicated that oil spillage over a period of time seems to be the main cause. I did not give the impression that it is the sole cause.

    I have also explained that towards the end of 1977, the weather situation was rather exceptional in that the amount of rainfall happened to be more than previous years. We have sufficient statistics to assure the Member that, as far as the expenditures on road patching for 1977, 1976 and 1975 were concerned, they were approximately the same. If he is interested, I will submit information to that effect. In other words, I am suggesting that it was nothing unusual except that towards the last few months of

Column: 947

1977, because of rainfall being heavier than normal, the expenditure was a little higher.

    However, since this is of concern to the Member for Telok Blangah as well as to a few other Members in this House, I would reiterate the stringent exercise carried out by PWD to ensure that the materials used for road surfacing are in accordance with specifications. The quality control measures taken include the following: the grading of the stone aggregate size is supervised; the bitumen content, the structural stability of the asphalt concrete, the temperature at the time of laying and the laying of the premix asphalt are also supervised. Samples of materials used at every stage are taken and sent to the PWD's laboratory for testing and analysis. If the asphalt arriving at the site is less than the minimum temperature, it is rejected. Substandard materials are also rejected. The newly laid layers are either taken off or an additional new layer of premix asphalt is added. The PWD also carries out surprise checks at the contractor's mixing plants and samples of the asphalt are sent again to the engineering laboratory for a test. So far, the tests carried out indicate that the materials comply with the PWD specification. Incidentally, the number of contractors for this type of work is limited. They are normally well screened before they am allowed to tender for road projects.

    I have also indicated in my Oral Answer in this House at that time that more than 80% of the damage to road pavements occurred at bus stops, bus lanes or at road junctions. This is due mainly to oil spillage over a period of time and this has the effect of softening and dissolving the asphalt in the road pavement and, therefore, resulting in a loss of the binding quality.

    The PWD is currently looking into the use of certain additives to prevent the asphalt paving from unravelling during continuous inclement weather. Its effectiveness will have to be tested and monitored over a period of time before we can come to the conclusion that a particular additive is most effective.

3.00 p.m.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Sir, the Senior Minister of State stated that since the sums expended on road repairs have been more or less the same for the last two to three years, he therefore thinks that the roads are equally well maintained. With inflation from year to year one would expect that the same number of repairs would cost more from year to year. Can we have an assurance from him that the roads which are in need of repair are not simply left unrepaired, as implied by the same level of expenditure from year to year?

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, statistically it could be interpreted the other way - that due to the efficiency of the Roads Department, the cost, despite inflation, has been kept at that same level. In other words, it indicates that the number of repairs is less than in previous years. To be fair to the PWD, a general observation would indicate that our roads are, by any means, of a reasonably high standard. Our roads are in a better condition now than they were five or six years ago.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, I have the highest consideration for the efficiency of the PWD. I am just wondering whether the Senior Minister of State himself has gone round to make sure that roads which are in need of repairs are being repaired. The PWD could simply be constrained by the budget.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, I think it is most unfair to expect me to go round inspecting the roads. Since the Member is agreeable that the PWD is efficient, I can assure him that the present system allows for notification of any areas which need to be patched up and I think they are being done as expeditiously as it is possible.

     Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Pasir): Sir, the maintenance of the pedestrian walkways in Singapore seems to be very slack indeed. I know that the PWD is constructing very beautiful new walkways along Orchard Road, but the old walkways in East Coast Road need to be repaired badly. There are trees growing in the centre of the walkway and pedestrians have to dodge these trees while

Column: 949

trudging down the walkway. In addition, the grass in between cement slabs has gone dry or overgrown. I have watched women with high heels walking gingerly over them and some even playing hop-scotch because they find it so difficult to trudge along the walkway. I am just wondering whether the Senior Minister of State would consider removing these hazards on pedestrian walkways and improving them in his maintenance programme i.e. those pedestrian walkways along East Coast Road and even along the NTUC building, for instance, and of course not to mention Lorong 8!

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, I think the Member for Potong Pasir has not got his facts right. When he talks about beautiful young ladies failing over, I think he is referring to areas where we put BG slabs. These slabs are laid at the base of trees planted in the central or suburban areas. If the Member can show me any walkway with BG slabs which cause an obstruction to pedestrians like him, I will be too happy to remove them.

    I am surprised he brought up the question of the walkway around the Singapore Conference Hall. The fact of the matter is this. The walkway along the Shenton Way frontage of the Singapore Conference Hall is 3.9 metres wide and it has a granulitic finish, which means it has a plain straight finish. It is in fairly good condition. On the other side of the Singapore Conference Hall, facing Maxwell Road, the walkway is 1.5 metre wide and it has a cement rendering, and it is also found to be in good condition.

     Mr Ivan Baptist: Sir, I am not speaking of the condition of the cement slabs. I am talking about the cement slabs that are being divided by portions of earth where grass is supposed to grow. These portions provide a hazard, a safety hazard which I believe very few of us want to face. Maybe before the Singapore Sports Council was set up, that was the time when Singaporeans needed a

Column: 950

little more exercise, there were no jogging tracks then, so the thought was that these walkways could be utilised as jogging tracks or for hopping from one slab to another. Now that the SSC has got sufficient jogging tracks, I am just wondering whether he could fill in those portions that are covered with earth, which are safety hazards, with cement.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, I choose not to go into a debate on this particular topic because it seems that we are talking of two different things. If he is talking about slabs around trees, yes, I concede that. I even concede that if the slabs are obstructing pedestrians, I am prepared to have them removed and replace them with beautiful coloured tiles. However, if he can be more specific about his complaint, I suggest that he write to me or to the Ministry of National Development and tell us exactly where it is, and I can assure him that we will do the necessary repairs that he wants.

     Mr Ahmad Haleem: Sir, in view of the explanation given by the Senior Minister of State, I beg leave to withdraw.

    Amendment by leave, withdrawn.

     Mr P. Govindaswamy: Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head N be reduced by $10 in respect of item 8102 of Subhead Code NC-02 of the Development Estimates*.

    Sir, sometime ago wide publicity was given to the Government's plan to build a Mass Rapid Transit System. Millions of dollars were voted for studies to be carried out and for subsequent developments. So far the cost of the total project amounted to $2,253,000. The estimates for 1977 was $680,000. This year the House is asked to approve only $38,950. I want to know why the provision is so low. What has happened to all the studies which were conducted previously? Are we still going ahead with the Mass Rapid Transit project? Could the Minister enlighten the House on the latest position of this project?

     Dr Ong Leong Boon: Sir, I just want to take this opportunity to reinforce the question which the hon. Member for Anson

Column: 951

has asked and, that is, what is the present position with regard to the Mass Rapid Transit System. Has the Government decided one way or another to go ahead, or to drop the plan altogether?

    Sir, we remember very distinctly that way back in 1973, when the present Senior Minister of State for Communications was one of us in the Backbench, he used to be one of the main spokesmen on this subject. It is already five long years and lots of money have been spent. If we look at the calculations, something like $2.89 million has been spent up to-date, that is, actual expenditure for 1976 plus the estimated expenditure for 1977. We know that Phase I has concluded; so is Phase 11. But we would like to know if all preliminary studies have been concluded or, in fact, there are still shortcomings in the studies. We would also like to know whether a more comprehensive study may be necessary and what decision the Government intends to take on this matter, knowing full well that with every month of procrastination in deciding on this matter, costs will go up.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang: Sir, to answer the question from the hon. Member for Anson, the provision of $38,950 in the FY 78 Estimates represents the residual amount from previously approved funds which are available for the mass transit study project. The funds are required to meet miscellaneous expenditure including communication with the consultants at the World Bank on the concluding stages of the consultants' report and the World Bank review.

    The position is that Phase I and Phase II studies have already been completed, as mentioned by the hon. Member for Kim Seng. The latest position in regard to the Mass Transit study programme will be given by the Senior Minister of State for Communications when this subject comes up for debate later under Head O, Ministry of Communications. I hope he will get the latest position from the Senior Minister of State for Communications.

     Mr Teo Chong Tee (Changi): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head N be reduced by $10 in respect of Subhead Code NE-01 of the Main Estimates.

    Sir, today more than half of the population of Singapore are living in flats and this number is expected to increase in future. In fact, the demand for HDB flats is so great that it is not possible for the Housing and Development Board to cope with. However, with the intensification of housing development in recent years, it is reported that the number of applicants waiting for flats has been reduced considerably. It is true that the waiting list is now shorter, but the waiting time does not seem to improve except for new towns like Woodlands and Clementi.

    Sad to know, we are now in a position where in certain housing estates people are waiting for flats to live in, whereas in other housing estates flats are waiting for people to live in. I am sure the HDB knows about this. However, has any action been taken to remedy this unhealthy state of affairs?

    Perhaps it is interesting to know how the HDB decides on the number of flats to be built in each housing estate each year. Does the HDB take the choice of the people into account when deciding on housing developments? It is obvious that certain housing estates are more popular than

Column: 953

others. Thus, to meet the demand of the people, the development programme in the less popular housing estates should be slowed down so that the limited resources can be mustered to intensify housing developments in the more popular housing estates.
3.15 p.m.

    It may be argued that the demand of the people could not be met in certain estates because land is limited.
